name: Turbo
desc: An independent design studio run by Saeed Abu-Jaber & Mothanna Hussein. Turbo’s website was a small, fun project that first started as a simple responsive static HTML website. It was later followed by an updated dynamic version built on top of Keystone.js backend, using the front-end developed in the first phase.

name: Welfare Map
desc:
An independent non-profit organization dedicated to sustainable development and humanitarian assistance to Palestinians in the West Bank.

The task at hand was to develop an interactive map that showcased the organization’s work in the Old City of Jerusalem.

The map was built using Google Maps Javascript API and node.js, and consisted of three different layers, each with a unique set of data and a different layout.

name: Jawwy
desc:
A new mobile service for Saudi youth from STC telecom which was designed and built by Frog design. I worked on the front-end development of the website’s Arabic version through Syntax during the first 3 sprints.

Working on this project was a unique experience, considering the scale of work needed to be done under a short amount of time while adhering to strict technology standards. The task was done remotely with the majority of the team — 32 designers and technologists — based in Milan.

name: KAFD
desc:
A non-governmental organization committed to enhancing productivity through implementing development projects that help alleviate poverty and unemployment.

I worked on this project during my time at Syntax, where I was responsible for the front-end development of a bilingual, responsive website for KAFD. My involvement covered the implementation of the interfaces up until the early final stages of the project. The project continued to be in development afterwards and went through a few changes which were carried out by Spring at that stage.

name: Al-Sharq Forum
desc:
A forum for sociopolitical content, events and youth engagement. I worked on the research, design, and front-end development of two different interfaces of a bilingual, responsive website: the main website and the administration area. The website encouraged engagement by allowing members to sign-up for calendar events, read and publish articles, participate in forums and communicate through an internal messaging system.

The design was broken down into small sprints. Each sprint went through four phases: research, sketching (lo-fidelity prototypes), HTML prototyping, and designing in browser. The result was a fully interactive design delivered to the client in the form of HTML files, which later served as the main templates for a backend built on top of a RoR framework.

name: RHC
desc:
The Royal Hashemite Court is considered the political and administrative link between His Majesty King Abdullah II and the Constitutional Authorities.

This was a unique project, considering its importance, scale, and the number of development cycles it had to go through. I worked on the front-end development of a bilingual responsive website where the HTML templates were customized to match the templates generated by Drupal CMS.

name: Qatar Social Work
desc: A non-profit organization for developing and building the capacity of civil society organizations in Qatar. I Just like the way it looks, so nothing technically special here — a small, simple responsive static HTML website.

name: Tiraz
desc: With over 2000 costumes and weavings, Tiraz is home to the world’s largest collection of Palestinian, Jordanian and Arab traditional customs from the 19th and 20th centuries. I worked on both the backend and front-end development of the website, which was built on top of Drupal 7 CMS.

name: Umniah
desc:
One of the main three mobile cellular telecommunication companies in Jordan. I worked as a consultant through Syntax on the front-end development of a bilingual online portal which consisted of three different sub-portals: the main website, the human resource portal and Umniah mobile.

The work on this project had to be broken into small rapid cycles between design, development and QA, given the gargantuan scale of the project that had to be accomplished by a small team under an ambitious time frame. The development and design for the interfaces were done in a modular, iterative, component-based approach. The result was a simple, modular interface, which provided users with a consistent experience across different pages and portals.
